results.abstract: Sen space com charges evasiveness, overconfidence and complacency by NASA officials contributed to Apollo fire; Sens Mondale, Brooke and Percy file harsher separate repts; Mondale cites rept to NASA on problems with North Amer Aviation, prime contractor for project, in '65; space com scores NASA's failure to inform Cong of difficulties; Mondale, Brooke and Percy comment; Repr Ryan describes rept as evasion of issue

headline.main: Senate Report Assails NASA on Apollo Deaths; Space Panel Says Agency and Prime Contractor Were Overconfident on Project

results.snippet: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI)--A Senate report issued today charged that evasiveness by Government space officials, compounded by "overconfidence and complacency," contributed to the Apollo spacecraft fire that took the lives of three United States...
results.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI)--A Senate report issued today charged that evasiveness by Government space officials, compounded by "overconfidence and complacency," contributed to the Apollo spacecraft fire that took the lives of three United States astronaut a year ago.

results.abstract: J M Culkin article on trend for young children to make own films; illus

headline.main: The Young in Search of Identity

results.snippet: TIM PAGE is a filmmaker. He is ten years old. He has a problem. His mother won't let him see any of Fellini's films. Cristina Rodriguez has just finished "My Movie," perhaps the first film ever done by a threeyear-old. A legend is already building...
results.lead_paragraph: TIM PAGE is a filmmaker. He is ten years old. He has a problem. His mother won't let him see any of Fellini's films. Cristina Rodriguez has just finished "My Movie," perhaps the first film ever done by a threeyear-old. A legend is already building around one 14-year-old who has more than 80 films in the can.

results.abstract: NASA studies reasons for scientist-astronauts' discontent; slowdown in space flight schedule due to budget cuts and lack of time for scientific research cited

headline.main: ASTRONAUTS SEEK TIME FOR STUDIES; Discontent Also Results From Slowed Flight Schedule

results.snippet: HOUSTON, Feb. 10 (UPI) -- The space agency, faced with the prospect of astronauts who are unhappy because their flight training leaves too little time for scientific research, is looking for a way to give its 16 scientist-spacemen the best of both...
results.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, Feb. 10 (UPI) -- The space agency, faced with the prospect of astronauts who are unhappy because their flight training leaves too little time for scientific research, is looking for a way to give its 16 scientist-spacemen the best of both worlds.

results.snippet: Soviet space officials are emerging with renewed confidence from a year of troubles, including the death of a astronaut in a crash landing last April, and are poised for a stepped-up drive leading to a manned flight around the moon, possibly by the...
results.lead_paragraph: Soviet space officials are emerging with renewed confidence from a year of troubles, including the death of a astronaut in a crash landing last April, and are poised for a stepped-up drive leading to a manned flight around the moon, possibly by the end of the year.

results.abstract: NASA to develop land vehicle or flying machine to explore as much as 10 mi of moon's surface; seeks funds in fiscal '69 budget as part of $439.6-million Apollo Applications Program request; flying unit described

headline.main: NASA to Develop Vehicles to Explore Surface of Moon

results.snippet: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 18 (AP) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration plans to start developing machines this year that will enable astronauts to drive or hop about on the surface of the moon.
results.lead_paragraph: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 18 (AP) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration plans to start developing machines this year that will enable astronauts to drive or hop about on the surface of the moon.

results.abstract: F J Mrkva, Passport Office field service branch chief, hon by Freedom Foundation for efforts to thwart Czech agents from planting listening devices in dept offices

headline.main: Freedom Foundation Honors Official Who Foiled Czech Reds

results.snippet: VALLEY FORGE, Pa., Feb. 21 (AP) -- A 35-year-old State Department official who placed himself and his family "in imminent danger through four four years" of anti-Communist spy work was named winner tonight of the Freedom Foundation's highest award.
results.lead_paragraph: VALLEY FORGE, Pa., Feb. 21 (AP) -- A 35-year-old State Department official who placed himself and his family "in imminent danger through four four years" of anti-Communist spy work was named winner tonight of the Freedom Foundation's highest award.

headline.main: Contemplating Ruffles for Men at 'Think Tank'

results.snippet: ON the runway, there were maxi coats and lacefrilled cuffs, capes and red shoes. But although several of the faces on the podium were familiar to the followers of women's fashions, the audience was predominantly male.

headline.main: Baylor, at Age of 33, Sparking Injury-Plagued Lakers' Drive

results.snippet: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 24 -- At an age when most basketball players begin to look for an easy chair and slippers, Elgin Baylor, the 33-year-old captain of the Los Angeles Lakers, is having one of his finest seasons as the National Basketball Association's...
results.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 24 -- At an age when most basketball players begin to look for an easy chair and slippers, Elgin Baylor, the 33-year-old captain of the Los Angeles Lakers, is having one of his finest seasons as the National Basketball Association's Complete Player.

headline.main: An Ecosystem Is A Partnership in Nature

results.snippet: SEALING a snail and a scrap of green elodea into an airtight test tube looks like certain death for the snail. Happily, the algae uses the carbon dioxide and other waste products from the snail to make food, and gives off oxygen as a by-product.
results.lead_paragraph: SEALING a snail and a scrap of green elodea into an airtight test tube looks like certain death for the snail. Happily, the algae uses the carbon dioxide and other waste products from the snail to make food, and gives off oxygen as a by-product.
